# Steps to reproduce

## 1. create and run an elf with a long name
```bash
➤ cat > test.c
#include <stdio.h>

int main(void)
{
    getchar();    
}
➤ gcc test.c -o a_long_long_long_name
➤ ./a_long_long_long_name&
[1] 26835
[1]  + 26835 suspended (tty input)  ./a_long_long_long_name
```
## 2. use Get-Process to find its name
```powershell
➤ pwsh
PowerShell 6.1.3
Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.

https://aka.ms/pscore6-docs
Type 'help' to get help.

/tmp
> Get-Process | Where-Object { $_.ProcessName.Contains('long') }

 NPM(K)    PM(M)      WS(M)     CPU(s)      Id  SI ProcessName
 ------    -----      -----     ------      --  -- -----------
      0     0.00       0.73       0.00   26835 607 a_long_long_lon
/tmp
> (Get-Process | Where-Object { $_.ProcessName.Contains('long') }).ProcessName
a_long_long_lon
```

# Expected behavior

I will get the full name of the process

# Actual behavior

I only got the first 15 characters of the process

# Environment data

<!-- provide the output of $PSVersionTable -->

```none
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.3

Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

I found `[System.Diagnostics.Process]::GetProcesses()` also did not give me the full name
It seems to be a bug of upstream https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/issues/34437

title: Get-Process doesn't give the full name of process
